Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 07:38PM ebann wrote: Susan; Having IBC my breast was double the size overnight. I went and saw my doctor the very next day. Within the week it was changing. My nipple almost disappeared and became inverted. It got an orange peel appearance. It became red like a rash all within a week. I was on antibiotics which did not help. This was normal for me, especially within the week. My doctor at first was treating me for masitis. After three weeks he sent me to a breast surgeon. The breast surgeon did a core biopsy that day. Came back on April 10th and dx me with IBC. Went to the oncologist and within in four days I had a PET scan, MUGA scan, port put in and then chemo started. As soon as the treatment of chemo started my breast became better. (within 3 weeks) I was very glad and happy with the progress when it started.  Believe me it is no fun and I wish this upon nobody. I just pray that the chemo will do everything it needs to do for you. My prayers and blessing are with you and your family. Blessings, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 07:43PM ebann wrote: Update: Just wanted to let everyone know that when I saw Dr. Ondreyco (oncologist) she referred me back to the radiologist to see if I can have radiation again to take care of the pain I have been experiencing. Dr Richmond (radiologist) said I cannot do radiation I have reached my max. So then both Dr.'s referred me to see an Orthopedic Surgeon. I did see him yesterday and had some x-rays done. Dr. Seidel (surgeon) says I need to have surgery for my hip/leg on the left side. He will burrow out the bone marrow and some of the bone that the cancer has been eating away. Then they will place a rod in my hip and one down my whole leg close to my knee attached to two screws. I am lucky cause I have not fractured my leg or hip which is better cause I will not have to do a replacement. Surgery is an hour long, hospital stay is 1 - 2 days will be walking right away and out of pain. Is that amazing or what! I am not looking forward to another surgery yet I am looking forward to being out of pain and off pain meds. Thank you for your support and prayers

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2008 12:30PM ebann wrote: Hi Wink; I am bipolar and am grateful that my medication does not interfer with my chemo or my chemo does not interfer with my medication. I am more of a depressive. I  take cymbalta which is really great for depression, aches, worries, generalized anxiety disorder, fibromyalgia, and diabetic nerve pain. Amazing drug.I take tradozone to sleep, cause I can be up for 3 weeks with no sleep and then finally crash for 2 days. I take risperdal, and lamictal these are mood stabilizers. Chemo put me into menopause so the stabilizers have really helped. My famiy was really concerned being dx with IBC that I would get very depressed, cause of my past. My medications make such a difference it is the first time in a long time that I have felt whatever normal is. I wish you the best with your decision and hope that you find a medication that really works well for you. It truly can make a big difference. I do take alot of medication for my disorder. But I do recommend the cymbalta plus it is not in high doses. Which is really nice. It takes time for these kinds of medications to take effect. At least 3 weeks. I found cymbalta did not take as long which was another benefit. Blessings;Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 01:25AM ebann wrote: mricha02; Wow your discussion is even in fast mode. Been there and done that many times without chemo. I am bipolar so this is a normal thing for me. But for me all the cocktails I have been on have basically knocked me out. I had a few hyper moments when taking steriods. Boy and do I love that feeling. Will not lie. love it! It is not easy to sit back and let others take care of you though it is something we learn while being on chemo and getting well. It all becomes so overwhelming we really do not know what to do with it all. I recommend you do your best to quiet your mind. Find some peace. Do something you enjoy like maybe read a book if you can't sleep. Watch a movie with the children, spend time on the computer. Ask the doctor for some meds to sleep and slow down your mind. You will finally crash and you will wonder what truly happened. Been there done that! I am glad that your husband is being helpful. It may not be in the mode or the way you would like it to be, but it is better than nothing. I appreciate everything my husband does for me. It may not be perfect and the way I do it is probably not either. The fact he is helping is a blessing. People care about you and you can come and rant and rave all you want. We are here for you. Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2011 06:34AM ebann wrote: Imixon: I can relate to what some of the things  your wife is going through. I was dx the 1st time with IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) My tumor was 12.5 cm, I am also a TN. I did Taxotere/Cisplatin, Adrimycin/Cytoxan, Taxol/Carboplatin radiation for 33 weeks for one year. Then I was NED for a year and a half. Got dx the 2nd time with bone mets to the spine, left femur, left hip, left area of the pelvis. Did Abraxane/Avasting for 4 months and radiation for 10 days. I did Abraxane/Avastin every wednesday for 3 weeks and 1 week off. I have been on Zometa ever since. Which helped with the pain I was experiencing at the time. Then after 4 months I started to experience pain in my left femur/hip. So I had MRI, x-rays, CT's, another PET Scan. They said that my spine mets was gone and the lesions everywhere else was shrinking. So I was very please with the process. So after all the tests I did they found out that the cancer was eating away the bone marrow in my femur/hip. So I had to stop chemo cause I could not have surgery while being on it. They replaced my femur/hip. I was on morphine and percocet and during those  4 months I just experienced pain even on the meds.  They found out when they went into my hip that my hip was fractured. I am now on a cane instead of a walker doing physcial therapy 3 times a week. I went in for another PET scan on July 6th cause I had been off chemo it has spread to my lower back vertebra, pelvis on the right, right femur, right humerous, multi lesions on my liver to many to count and in my glands and nodes. I am now on Taxotere/Carboplatin. I do every  Wednesday for 3 weeks and 1 week off. I love my one week off.  I thought you are not allowed to repeat chemo's.  They are now doing Target Tumor Profiling. Which if the receptors are the same as 1st dx then you can repeat a chemo that worked for you. So this chemo worked last time and praying it works this time. Has  your wife considered a Advanced Breast Cancer Support Group or counseling? My Dr. has also put me on meds cause of depression. This my be something  your wife my want to consider if she seems to be going down that road. I have started to do both since my 3rd dx. It has been a much more emotional roller coaster for me this time. It is hard to even believe I am losing my hair for the 3rd time.  Remember that Stage 4 does not mean it is a death sentence. Though I know it is hard not to think about. I have done many things to prepare my family just in case. I hate even going there. My purpose in life is my family and friends. I am really sorry to hear that  your wife is having to face this. You sound like  a wonderful caregiver what a blessing that is for your wife. My husband is too. That is amazing that your wife is still working. I give her a lot of credit. I worked with children and my Dr. said I could not work because children are a germ factory and my blood counts have not been the best. I have heard wonderful things about M.D. Anderson. I believe you are in good hands. Do you have any children? If so how are they handling this? Do you have a support group for yourself? Are you and your wife able to talk about other things than cancer? Also for nausea and stomach upset ginger capsules are wonderful. You can take up to 3 / 3 times a day. If you take to many they can cause acne. My naturopath recommended them too. I would also ask your Dr. about Metformin. It is a diabetic drug and is working on women who are TN and shrinking the tumors. I know a lady from my support group that had a tumor in her brain a size of a baseball and it was inoperative. They put her on metformin and it shrinked it down to a pencil size. So please ask! This is about the Target Tumor Profiling.  This is probably not for your wife at this time but you never know if you might need it. http://www.carislifesciences.com/caris-target-now-patient-stories http://foodforbreastcancer.com/news/metformin-suppresses-metastasis-of-triple-negative-breast-cancer-cells Many Blessings to you and your wife, Elizabeth

She suffered through a lot of things. She had to have a mastectomy, all but one breast. She had pyometria. She had to have emergency surgery. She followed me everywhere. I went through some really hard times and she was there for me. I finally got another dog. I love her and her name is Peggy Sue. Just she can never replace my sweetie. She meant so much to me. When she passed I was devastated. I can only imagine what it is that you are feeling. I would of been in shock too. I have been. You made a wise decision. Your daughter is amazing. Children say the darnedest things. She is so right and I am sure that what she said brought you great comfort from some a little heart. I feel for you. May time pass by and get easier for you. May your memories be sweet. I am thinking of you and your family. Blessings;Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 05:10PM ebann wrote: I had a DIEP in 2010. I am very pleased with the results. When I spoke to my PS he told me he would not do a TRAM. If the flap did not  take then there would be nothing we could do about it. I did not have enough skin to put under me. My chest was concaved cause of how large the tumor that was there. I wish you the best on making your decision. Let us know what you decide.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 11:48PM ebann wrote: First you need to get all the information in regards to what stage she is in,  what grade whether is postive or negative receptors but she will not get that till after the surgery or biopsy my be able to tell that. If they caught it early then that is a really good sign. I am glad to hear that you have a great relationship with  your mom and she has the support she needs. Let her know of BCO it is a wonderful place to come too. Your mom will have to do the MRI so they can get a better deeper look at her breast. They will decide on what the best plan is to do. She may need a lumpectomy or a mastectomy, she may need chemo or maybe she will not. She may need radiation or she may not. There are so many and it really depends on the staging of her breast. I am glad that someone will be going to her appts with her that is important cause it is hard to remember everything that is being said all at once. May sure each day counts and make time for your mom she will need your support more than anything. I hope she only has miminal to do. That would be such a blessing. Remember that whatever your mom's age is then you need to get your done 10 years earler  your mammograms that is. Or you are to begin when you are 40. Take care of yourself as will.  Have a positive attitude and be strong for your mom and yourself. Remember it is okay to cry and break down it is not easy to hear the word cancer. You can always come on here if you need to chat or put something up on the discussion board. Wish     you all the best in this journey.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 11:30PM ebann wrote: I go to a couple of support groups. Sometimes you have to try a few out to see which one is best for you. I go to an advanced bc group. Which has been very educational for me. The support is good too. I also go to one at the wellness community center. There are some throughout the US. They are free, have many things to offer and have professional counselors leading the group. I think it is wonderful to hear others in what you are going through. The online support group is good but I feel it is not as personal as seeing the person. I started a support group in 2008 here in AZ. I coordinate activities to do each month so that we are able to have fun. We go to coffee shops, lunch, musuems, tea parties, ornament exchange at Christmas, the spa, etc. It is wonderul to be with other women. I hope that you find one that is good for you. It really can make a difference.

My onc told me it is rare to find that at the same time as I did. My bs gave me an option of having a mastectomy on the left breast and an lumpectomy on the right breast. She told me the changes was me getting cancer on the right breast again would be rare. I decided to go with a radical double mastectomy. I had currently went through chemo and had Taxotere, Cisplatin then Admircyin, then surgery, now there is still cancer in my chest wall and lymphs so I have to do a combination of chemo Taxol, & Carboplatin with rads. Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 01:13AM ebann wrote: I am on steroids and yes you definatily are wired. I have been taking them for sometime now. I take melatonin at night 20mg and then my Dr. prescribed me Ambien to sleep. This has helped me. As far as the weight gain my Dr said there is really nothing that can be done. Just that when you are finished it will come off. I had experienced this during my 1st dx. The weight did come off. It was depressing cause I gained 60 lbs. So far that is not the case for me  this time around.  I keep losing weight. My  Dr. says it is my liver mets. For bloating and swelling you can take a duiretic prescribed by the Dr. This helps as well. A lot of women has these issues. I am sure that others will chime in. I have found to that it really effects my mood. I do not like it. I take my steriods Tuesday, Wednesday they give them to me with my chemo then on Thursday. I do not know what your schedule is. I do this for 3 weeks then I am off a week. I hope this helps.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 08:29PM ebann wrote: Hi Kim, I know what you mean...It is not easy to get back into the groove of things. As my Dr. told me to take it easy as you are regaining your energy back. I would talk to your boss and see if you are able to stay on part time. As long as you are okay with that. I am sure it would be nice to have more income but you do need to take care of you. Make sure you are taking vitamins. If you need to sit down and things at home are not done in the timely fashion. Do not worry about it. Do one thing at a time. Just divide it up into small portions. So do the laundry, fold and put away the next day. Cook some meals and have some meals that are easy to do. Like crockpot  meals. Already done when you get home and left overs. As far as walking the dog. Limit the time you take her. It may be 10 min but that is better than nothing. Get the rest you need on the weekends. If that means sleeping half a day then do it. As far as work with the co workers. I think I would say something like. It is good to be back but I really am not interested in hearing about all the complaints. I just went through cancer and am still dealing with getting back on my feet. Can you respect that! Just a suggestion. Take care of yourself. It is important!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 11:23PM ebann wrote: Hi everyone, I had IBC (inflammatory breas cancer) and DCIS in the other breast.  The tumor was 9 cm and continued to  grow during chemo to 12.5 cm . I did chemo first for 9 months. My tumor did not shrink. I went in and did a radical mx. They found out it spread to my chest wall. I started up with rads and I had to continue for chemo for another 4 months. Went in for a PET scan and it was NED. I did reconstruction a year later. My chest was so concaved that I was not able to do TE and Implants. So I had a DIEP. I was cancer free for a year and a half. It has now spread to my bones, nodes, glands, lower vertabre, neck and most of all in my liver to many lesions to count. I have been doing chemo for a year now. I am hoping to go on maintenance soon. We shall see. When I was first dx with IBC I was stage 3B now of course I am stage 4. I am a fighter. I am grateful i have my faith, family and friends that get me through.

I would rather my Dr. be cautioius and think of my wellbeing. You just do not mess with cancer. I understand your frustiration. You may not get lymphodema at all. It can happen at anytime or not all. I got me a bracelet I wear all the time. That says no IV or BP on the left arm Lymphodema. That way if something happens to me they no not to use that arm. Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 10:13AM ebann wrote: At first being bald was such a shock to me. I never imagined I would ever be bald either. I loved having my hair done and coming up with new styles. Though living in Arizona to wear a hat or wig was really hot. So I made a choice of walking around bald. After awhile it did not bother me at all. So it just became the thing to do. Everyone has been kind and said what a nicely shaped head I have. I suppose I do. Though I do have to say when it is cold you sure do feel it on your head. I am not ashamed of having cancer and this is just one of the things we have to face. So be it. My hair is coming in and I am fine walking around this way too. It is just part of the process in getting well. I am proud of you. I wish you the best and hope you will be over this hill soon enough. I have 3 more chemo treatments and I am praying it is over soon. I just finished radiation  4 days ago. Take care,  Elizabeth
